review_title: Varying Degrees of Responsibility, Same Pay
pros:
Graduate Assistant positions are built into the graduate program and prioritize your course/studio schedule. 

The positions are primarily in the school of art and occasionally in the graduate school itself (ex: photographer/social media for the graduate school). 

These positions are either *super* easy and require little to no specific skills (ex: monitor the digital lab) or they are more technical and hands-on, in which case the department will provide training and it's a GREAT opportunity to get practical experience in a field or medium you don't have expertise in (ex. darkroom photography or the foundry).
cons:
As a result of some of the assistantship positions being easier and requiring less tasks and responsibilities (like monitoring a computer lab) ... some grad students are able to incorporate reading and writing assignments and even sometimes more studio time into their assistantship hours while other grads have a more intensive assistantship that requires them to actually work during their work hours... so they do not have the same luxury of time. This creates a pretty equitable working and learning environment. 

In addition, each assistantship is supervised differently and some assistantships, though they exist on paper... some grads will only put in a handful of hours at the end of the semester rather than 20 per week over the course of three months.

job_title: ITS Lab Consultant in Greensboro, NC
pros:
Moderately flexible hours, easy to take shifts.
If someone works the graveyard shift, they make a promotion wage.
A relaxed atmosphere, allows you to work on homework easily.
Managers are nice.
cons:
Most people are nice, some are rude.
Most of the time, you will be uninformed about the decisions the leads are making. We learned one day that we were not closing at 9:45 as we thought, but we were closing at 11:15 instead. We learned this from the department neighboring us. 
Base pay is minimum wage, $7.25, and is increased (to $8.50) if you have a previous degree (associates or bachelors) or if you are promoted.
This is not intended to be a full-time position. This is a part-time position where you are limited to 28 hours a week.

review_title: Works as a community, values improving brand
pros: Many and friendly and willing to lend a helping hand, or guide you in the right direction. For students, they work with your course schedule in order for you to balance academics and work. Overall academics is priority being that you cannot work more than a specific amount of hours (think its 30) on campus and with specific jobs.
cons: In some jobs offered on campus such as Residence and Housing Life, HRL, it can be difficult balancing working during your final year (senior year or semester you plan to graduating). The reason for this is that while you may be trying to balance final deadlines for courses in order to graduate you also are dealing with responsibilities of checking out residents that live in your hall. This can be very overwhelming and i found the organization for graduating students to be unfair and stressful by not encouraging graduating students to concentrate on graduating priorities.  Also if you are graduating, i found it difficult to have family visit and HRL offered little time off to celebrate with family.  It is very frustrating. All in all consider whether you want to work or not during your final semester at school.

pros: Good work environment and staff.
cons: There were no cons could think of.

review_title: It's good if you want a job in college
pros: The family atmosphere, pretty easy job, college environment and good scheduling. You usually get the schedule you want except training. Amazing coworkers.
cons: Extremely underpaid for a CPR professional certified individual, micromanaged way too often, Pro staff gives training's at the worst times and days. Training every month is truly unnecessary especially if you understand what they're going to go over in the class. This is especially bad for commuters because some of the employees end class in the morning but work wants us to come in at 6:00pm. Some workers commute 30+ minutes  to attend a 1 hour meeting when you have tests and things to do the next day. "They said they're about student advancement and growth" but you're restricted to advance into a management position until you finish a year of employment which I believe if you can prove yourself and they think you're ready, you should be allowed to apply for a management position.

review_title: Conventional, bureaucratic, and limited opportunities for advancement
job_title: Administrative Support Specialist in Greensboro, NC
pros: Good benefits, attractive campus, central location, variety of activities, interesting mix of students, art museum
cons: HR practices are abysmal and administration is unfair in treating employees equally.  Many employees get caught in under-paying jobs with limited opportunity for advancement because promotion is restricted to only a certain percentage increase in specific salary.  Faculty get all the respect and staff are overlooked in terms of the value they add to the campus, leadership is especially bureaucratic and closed to those who are not judged worthy, no raises to keep up with cost of living, morale is especially low.  Policies are in place to keep the low earners at the bottom, while the people who earn more are more easily promoted and gain more significant increases in compensation.

review_title: Working for UNCG is both rewarding and challenging.
pros: The University of North Carolina at Greensboro harbors a very diverse community that allows you to work with students of all different backgrounds, race/ethnicity, age, etc.  My most awarding experiences have come from helping others in this community find their niche at UNCG.  I absolutely love this school and the small-school-feel that it has, although it is home to over 18,000 students.
cons: I have not had many, if any, negative experiences while working or attending UNCG.  The good outweighs the bad in nearly every single situation.

pros: Great benefits and retirement plans.  Flexible hours (such as the option of working four 10 hour days instead of a traditional five day work week) allows for a better work/life balance.  The University system is very supportive of continued education and training and will pay for you to pursue additional degrees.
cons: Pay is not as high as the private sector can be, but the benefits make up for it (not much of the private sector offers pension plans anymore).  Also, being a large state run organization, things tend to move slow. So if you are the kind of person that likes to expediate projects and implement changes rapidly, you will probably be frustrated on a regular basis.

review_title: I love teaching and this is a good university.
pros: The faculty and staff are professional and inspiring.  The students are engaging and for the most part bright, ambitious and talented.
cons: You are working for the State of North Carolina - subject to their political whim.  It's an Currently it is an unstable environment - as an adjunct I didn't even know if I had class until two weeks before school is to begin.  That's not enough time to prep - order books to be available - hardly to plan anything.  It's unfair to the teacher and even more unfair to the students.

review_title: Graduate Assistant in Department of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures
pros: The compensation was great compared to what many graduate students face. Thanks to the assistantship, I was able to leave with a graduate degree and no debt. For the most part, the department was super flexible, supportive, friendly and encouraging. I did some research and editing for professors, and they were almost always very appreciative. I also did some tutoring and teaching of courses and felt very supported in my role.
cons: Every work place has its negative characteristics. I can remember some particular incidents where I may have gotten frustrated or disappointed in something work related, but those were exceptions and not the rule. This was a great place to work.

pros: I love working with the kids. The arts and sciences are so important to building our youth and I enjoyed helping the children learn more in a non-academic setting.
cons: The admin staff was ill equipped to handle a camp of that magnitude resulting in an insane amount of stress on the counseling and teaching staff. The lack of organization and proper training was truly the most daunting flaw of the camp.

pros: I know that all schools and departments on campus are different. I don't want to reveal my department here but I can name a school I work for. It is the School of Education. The faculty in my department are very dedicated to their work and they are supportive of each other. There's no reason for us to compete with each other because we are all different and it is in our best interest to support our colleagues. The university has plenty of resources for the professors to do their jobs. Also, the university is very conscious about the amount of support for their new faculty so the new faculty will have good guides to help them through the first couple of years. The dean of the School of Education is great. She listens to the faculty and she shows she cares about all faculty and staff in her school.
cons: As with all research-focused universities, the amount of stress for assistant professors is astronomically high and the amount of work that they have to do is unbelievable. Since the professors do different work, it can be isolating. It is true for me since my work is very different from the rest of the faculty in the department. Also, there is some tension between the departments but it is coming from older faculty members. The new faculty members are very interested in collaborating with each other and getting past the tension. One thing that the university can't control is the budget so it is always a concern for us, but the dean of the School of Education always find a way to make sure that the faculty are safe.

job_title: Senior Resident Adviser in Greensboro, NC
pros: Great experience, you will learn about and work with various departments on campus. A great way to start building connections and your resume early in your career.
cons: A lot of expectations as far as time commitment and ability to juggle school work and the position. Can be a bit stressful during heavy duty shifts.

review_title: Great place to be mentored, enjoyable work environment.
pros: I really enjoy working here, friendly professional staff who really want help students and GA reach their full potential. During my time working here, I started working on stuff above my job description which led to a promotion and a position created for me. Which shows that they really are intuitive to the needs of the employees and University.
cons: With any University or state job, the compensation is lower than the same position in a corporate workplace.

review_title: Great experience working for UNCG Rec Center
pros: Working for the UNC Greensboro Rec Center was one of my favorite college experiences! We truly became a family after several weeks, I don't know what I would have done without my amazing coworkers.
cons: I don't believe there were any, other than working for minimum wage and working on holidays. No downsides.

review_title: Staff salary held down in  academic departments
pros: Beautiful campus.  Variety of tasks makes work interesting. Most people are very pleasant.
cons: A lot of the upstairs/downstairs attitude between faculty and staff.  Staff salaries will never be allowed to rise to meet faculty, no matter what your job description or how well you perform your job.

cons: Workers are not always informed about change of personal and new employee policies. Heating services fail sometimes specially when extremely cold in winter.

review_title: GA - I thoroughly enjoyed working here!
pros: As a GA, I gained research experiences outside of the classroom that significantly aided in my education. There was a good work life balance and I was also able to receive funding towards my education.
cons: I don't really have any cons to add. Maybe inability to work more than 20 hours per week. That is probably a legal issue though.

pros: Love being apart of this University been employed at UNCG for 31 Years
cons: None now they Raised the Pay for Housekeeping to 15 dollars an hour. Several of my fellow Housekeepers work 2 jobs just to make ends meet!

pros: I love my subject and truly enjoy the institution and the students themselves.  Although the pay is low I feel appreciated by the other faculty.
cons: The pay is terrible.  The stability is terrible.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Greensboro, NC
pros: The surrounding faculty are fantastic -- everyone pulls their own weight and are willing to reach across colleges and disciplines to create some fabulous university-wide events, readings, and visiting speakers.
cons: The students are lackadaisical and often teaching feels less rewarding because of it -- of course, this fluctuates depending on the course level and requirement of the class.

pros: Some departments are great to work with/for; if you can last long enough, receiving the retirement and health insurance helps later down the road
cons:
Office politics is a real problem!  Some people should be eliminated, especially when many complaints are already registered with HR against these folks -  don’t trust HR, they won’t support you and nothing seems to change. 
Pay raises are slim to none; one year we received a week of vacation and a NC pin

review_title: It's about what you'd expect from academia
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Greensboro, NC
pros: Teaching is fulfilling for some, I hear, and your coworkers won't suck too terribly.
cons: When you teach, you suddenly become a 24 hour email concierge to a student body that is - mostly - pretty awful. There are plenty of crazy people in academia. You'll get to meet them.

pros: The job hours are very flexible for students to fit around they're school schedule. The job is easy to learn how to do. There is plenty of time to work on school work.
cons: Not a lot of upward mobility. You can only hold a position while you're a student at UNCG. The job can be boring sometimes.

pros: The environment here is very friendly and people are given high importance. Students and Faculties were asked to engage remotely when the Covid19 pandemic hit the city. Also, people here are very friendly and ready to guide you whenever you ask
cons: The high cost of Health Insurance provided by the state government

review_title: Great place to work as a student!
pros: Being a graduate assistant allows you to still put your school first and to get to know the faculty and staff firsthand. You also get to work on projects you are interested in and network with other professionals.
cons: Pay is not great since it is a public university.

review_title: Wonderful Part-Time Job for a Student
pros: Office is organized, paid training, raises after each level of training completed, parties throughout the semester, kind staff, you always get the hours you want, option to do online and in-person tutoring
cons: Might assign you more hours than you indicate depending on request load for the semester

review_title: Experience depends on your coworkers and supervisors, but you'll learn a lot.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Greensboro, NC
pros: Great at matching your class schedule. Gained a lot of experience with administrative and research work.
cons: Experience heavily reliant on the professor you are assigned to assist. It can be great, or not so great. Regardless, you'll learn a lot.

job_title: Senior Teaching Assistant in Greensboro, NC
pros:
Camaraderie. 
Kindness of the staff. 
Opportunities to do research with faculty.
Opportunities to teach different courses and to receive feedback from peers, students, and other faculty.
cons: In my experience, none. I'm pretty happy there.

pros: Easy access, great connection, good skill set, you can always count on a good and personal interaction with customers and patrons
cons: Can get very extensive and staffing is a little stale. Management is very shady and can sometimes get unprofessional don't be a fair to express your concerns

pros: Average compensation, talented staff, treated like a professional, trusted like a professional, and many opportunities to learn more. LOTS of student contact.
cons: High work load, but manageable and challenging in a good way.

job_title: Environmental Service Tech in Greensboro, NC
pros: Wonderful people, great benefits, paid vacation, opportunity for advancement, educational advancement.
cons: Can take time to get hired. Essential personnel must work during bad weather. Budget cuts.

pros:
- When you have free time, you can do homework.
- Great interaction between clients and employees
- Very flexible with your schedule
cons: - With IT, there are always delays. Expect this to occur.

pros: Nice people to work with.  Student interaction is great.  Overall, a good job.
cons: State employee, so you may experience "retroactive pay cuts", no salary increases, worry about if you have enough seniority to keep your job when budget cuts come around.

pros: The people at DCL are amazing. Always doing something fun and so friendly.
cons: It's not their fault, but the novelty of their location wears off real fast if you're not really wanting to put down roots and stay long-term.

pros: Many people around you that will become your friends and support you
cons: Pro-staff can sometimes act more like a buddy than a boss and it can cause problems

pros: Benefits were good. Graduate students were offered tuition waivers and student health insurance.
cons: Not much diversity or educational background amongst permanent employees which made being supervised by them a little awkward.

review_title: Seeking full time employment after retirement
job_title: Professional Standards Unit Commander in Greensboro, NC
pros: 28 + years law enforcement experience
cons: No cons working at my current job

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Greensboro, NC
pros: Great teaching experience, supportive environment, independence fostered
cons: Looked down on for having multiple jobs, even though the salary was small.

pros: very diverse group of people and very involved in the community. lots of opportunities for professional development
cons: low salaries but remember, you're working for the state. everything is contingent upon the General Assembly!

pros: Friendly people and happy environment. I work for the department of management, I met the greatest professor there. I am happy to work with them.
cons: Nothing is bad in this department. Everyone is nice here.

pros: The managers care about student employees a lot just. They are very resourceful when helping me in difficult situations. The meetings are straight-forward and can be very enjoyable.
cons: Pay rate is closed to the minimum wage

review_title: Young PhD program on the rise
pros:
State-of-the-art instrumentation and core facilities
Hands on experience
Approachable faculty and staff
Young, energetic faculty with innovative research goals
Collaborations with future job potential
cons: Small university still making a name for itself

pros: They are willing to train you no matter what kind of work history you have!
cons: Sometimes there is nothing to do so you sit there bored

pros: Inclusive and diverse community open to a wide array of individuals.  Great place to learn about interacting with those who are different from yourself.
cons: Occasional unfulfilling work that turns into busy work

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant/Teaching Assistant in Greensboro, NC
pros: Great research faculty. Friendly work/research environment. Challenging and rewarding. Research and grant writing skills are heavily emphasized throughout the curriculum.
cons: Expand the health and human sciences departments (Biology, Chemistry, etc.)

review_title: Great way to develop knowledge and skillsets as a student
pros: Great opportunity to grow in your field through various projects with different professors
cons: Pay isn't great if the main goal is compensation

pros: closer to the management level, work load varies from day to day, career advancement options. They like to higher from within.
cons: Cant think of any as of yet!

pros:
-friendly environment
-great community all around
cons: -classes are getting crowded so in turn more difficult to register for classes as well as getting a parking spot.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Greensboro, NC
pros: Nice work environment! Great job if you are looking for teaching experience, you learn a lot. Good work-life balance.
cons: The salary is not great.

pros: General sense of community and shared purpose.
cons: University pay rates are none competitive with industry

review_title: small university with limited resources to support faculty research
pros: good location, small campus,  friendly people
cons: lack of resources to support faculty development

review_title: Great place to work with awesome flexibility
pros:
Set your own schedule
Paid training to help you build skills
cons: Unable to freelance with your tutees

pros:

cons: -Hard to park somewhere if you don't live on campus

pros: Great people worked there and were a pleasure
cons: pay wasn't great but i wasn't there for long.

pros: High energy cooperative environment with great co workers

pros: Nice campus, supportive faculty members
cons: Reputation and ranking are not good and make it hard to find a good job position.

pros: Flexible hours for students were given.

pros: Low pressure, good lifestyle balance

cons: with $8.5/hour the salary isn't the best
